column4: Here's my problem: lately I've had a hard time logging onto SSH by remote. Sometimes the connect dies after giving pw, sometimes after displaying "last login" but before the prompt. Is this just SSH being unstable?
Should I set up something like automatic restart of ssh in crontab, or will that not help, you think?
I thought so as well... it's just annoying that my machine is on another continent and I'd need to ask a human being to look into it
it worked fine at firsrt
now the machine has been on nonstop for a month, so I don't know if this is a sign of it degenerating
well, yea, I suppose I could change the port... but unfortunately, I'd need to be able to login successfully once :/
I haven't looked at the logs lately, but I think it's not very likely that someone has discovered that port and is massively hammering at it
I'm running apache on another port and that one is running fine
well, I'm talking about the ssh daemon, possibly that one might need a kick once in a while
sshd is typically extremely stable.
brute-force dictionary attacks aren't all that uncommon
which port is that?
anyway, with a lot of automated attack tools now, if they do get in, you won't see the login attempt because your logs get changed.
knockd
the knockd I saw on sourceforge looks very easy to configure and run
they time out on their own, typically.  Especially if you're getting a "connection closed by remote host" error or similar.
what happens after that?
well, it could be... I don't know, though, the connection shouldn't be THAT lagged
so you just get no response or feedback at all, basically, you're saying?  It hangs rather than boots you?
running anything else besides apache, bittorrent, and ssh?
those are about it, no big server-thing
man that's a bummer.
